ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A solid understanding of the major trends and regional challenges in Gulf politics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No change, the course is brilliant. Prof. Jenkins forces you to rise to the occasion, his depth is unmatched which means the students have to be prepared. His style shaped my thinking and broadened my perspective to the point where I was personally invested in providing a new perspective that hopefully engaged and stimulated the professor's thinking in the same way he managed to influence mine.

Ambassador Jenkins has a deep understanding of the region's history and politics. The reading list was also very good. The class could perhaps benefit from a bit more structure in the discussion, but it was a great course overall.
The class discussions and Amb. Jenkins' perspective were all really interesting. Some of the readings were a bit dry, though--I might've preferred a few books instead.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, Prof. Jenkins is a distinguished expert on the subject, with the academic and royal titles, and real-world, high-level experience to back it up. An unusual combination in academics, he can serve the historical to present-day context on any middle eastern country with perfection and immeasurable depth. I have never encountered a person who can recite as much history and insight without the aid of slides or other "lecture materials". Not only an encyclopedia, but expert facilitator who incorporates the lecture with commentary from the students brilliantly.
Yes, this course will cover a region and controversies that aren't commonly discussed in other academic spaces.
Absolutely, if you are interested in the subject matter.
